On Tuesday 28 June 2005 17:02, Cedric Beust wrote:

> At any rate, the testing framework should give you the option. 

That's not clear to me: there are too many options for any given framework
to be able to offer in advance, so that it doesn't offer *this* option 
isn't necessarily a touch against it.

> You shouldn't have to modify your production code just to accomodate 
> the whims of a testing framework 

Isn't saying "whims" rather begging the question? If those "whims"
are an expression of good design, then you *should* be prepared to
modify production code to fit it into the framework. In the OPs
case, they don't *have* to change their production code to fit into
JUnit; they just have to ensure that each test runs through all the
appropriate state-dependencies. 

> (note that this claim is different from "write your
> production code to make it as easy to test as possible").

Another claim is "using a test framework may reveal design
issues in your production code that you may want to fix."

-- 
Chris "electric hedgehog" Dollin
It's called *extreme* programming, not *stupid* programming.
